Reviews.Content: Although disappointed to be despatched to the Holiday Inn Express Rome East for the first night, we were transported back in good time for a splendid breakfast the following day. Hotel is close to number 85 bus stop as described in other reviews - easy access to Colosseum and Forum as well as the Pantheon. Metro line A with access to everything else 10 minutes away. Don't bother with Shuttle/metro transfers from Ciampano unless you are on a budget. The Metro journey was dire (rush hour) and busy Romans just push you out of the way (much as we do to tourists in London I suppose!). The return to Ciampano was only 20 euro for the two of us (and our luggage) and took less than 20 minutes (2 hours on way out). Our room was good with a balcony overlooking the courtyard. You could still hear the trains and planes with the windows open, but not when closed. Maid service excellent. As you gather from other reviews the breakfasts were amazing- loads of variety and standard very high. Avoid Italian bank holiday weeks if possible. Standing in a queue for the Vatican Museum 2.5 hours in a thunderstorm is not a lot of fun and probably insane. (The umbrella sellers did well, with price becoming proportional to the rainfall!)

Reviews.Title: “A little gem”
Reviews.Author: MonkeyNottingham
Reviews.Content: Hotel prices in Rome are generally some of the highest in Europe and so it was great to find this affordable hotel in easy reach of the city centre. The hotel in ten minutes walk from the Ponte Lungo underground station (line A) that allows easy and cheap access to the city centre. A standard ticket is only one euro and within 10 mins you can be standing in the centre of one of the world's most beautiful city centres. The hotel is a modern built building in a largely residential area with clean spacious air conditioned rooms and nice bathrooms. Breakfast is included in the price and is a buffet affair with a wide choice on offer. Although there are not a huge amount of restaurants in the immediate area, it is cheap and easy to get to the city centre whether it be by the underground or by taxi. If using a taxi, make sure you are strapped in as driving in Rome is not for the faint hearted. In fact, unless you have to, don't drive in Rome. The number of dents on cars is for a reason! Our stay at the hotel was most enjoyable and was a perfect base to see the city. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel”
Reviews.Author: xxheath
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the holiday inn for three nights in April, I booked two rooms, one with priority points, the other direct by the website. The hotel is very clean, comfortable and in a nice area outside rome called Tuscolona (its about two metro stops from San Giovanni iteself - and the Cathedral there - not within walking distance). The room istelf had only two English Channels, CNN and MTV but Movies were 11 euros and were in English. Breakfast was very nice, lots of choice and run from 6.30-10.30 Mon-Sat and 7.30-11.30 Sun. The hotel bar isnt very well stocked, each time we tried to get a drink they had ran out of wine, orange juice etc. They also ran out of milk sachets so we couldnt make tea / coffee in the room. The aircon also broke while we were there - however dont let this put you off as the hotel itself is very pleasant, modern and clean - staff are very nice and speak good english. To get around Rome you need to use public transport. To go to San Giovanni Cathedral, Colloseum, Forum, Trevi Fountain - get the 85 Bus (turn right out of the hotel doors, go down the street, turn right onto Via Tuscolona and you will see the bus stop). There is a news agent stand where you can buy your tickets, 1 euro for 75mins from the moment you validated your ticket (you must buy a ticket, get on the bus at the back doors, put your ticket into the little machine to validate it, and when you get off the bus, press the button to stop and get off the front doors). The 75 min ticket is valid for unlimited bus journeys and one metro journey. However, its best to buy a one day, two day, three day pass etc. that you can use on any bus or metro. The bus 85 runs to at least 11.30pm, possibly longer. To get to San Giovanni, Trevi Fountain by metro (both stops named as per the attractions) instead of the bus 85 and also to get to the following sights, Spanish Steps (Stop Spagna) Vatican Museums (Stop Cipro) St Peters Basillica (Stop Ottavia) get the Metro (from Punto Lungo near the hotel). To get to this stop turn right out of the hotel, go down the street, turn right onto Via Tuscolona, go under the rail bridge past the flower stall and take the left turning after the flower stall, go up to the top of the road and you will see the Metro there. (red line A - it will also take you to and from the Termini in about 7 stops, 10 mins). The metro shuts at 11.30pm (opens 5.30am) and is by far the quickest and easiest way to get around. From the hotel to the Vatican City (furthest away point in rome) its only 20mins. They are the only two methods of transport you will need. You can walk to everywhere else from the stops that I mentioned. We flew to Ciampino and could have got a cheap bus ticket to the Termini then hopped on the metro. However we got a taxi which was 50 Euros each way (four people in a luxury mini van with two piceces of luggage each). We pre-booked this but there is lots of taxi's outside and a luxury taxi desk just inside arrivals where you can get one there. We ate in two restaurants near to the hotel. The best one was called Torquito. Turn right out of the hotel, go to the bottom of the road, turn left onto Tuscolona and walk for 10 mins straight up the road - the restaurant is on the right hand side of the road, just down a side street although the Taverna Torquito neon sign is clearly visable from the main road. Not much english is spoken, they sell pasta and steaks etc. but the service is very good and food is excellent. Its less pricy than rome (18 Euros for a good fillet steak) and more enjoyable. If you want to eat in Rome there are plenty of places aroudd the trevi fountain / pantheon area - and you can then get the bus back from the bus terminal near trevi fountain or the metro. Piazza Navona a 5 min walk from the Pantheon has lots of nice restaurants, but they are the most expensive in Rome. Hope this helps!

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel and Value!”
Reviews.Author: josehomes
Reviews.Content: My wife and I were in November 2006 for one night only and paid with reward points. Wish have stayed longer. Nice and superclean clean modern hotel, superb breakfast with plenty of variety and fresh capuccino made in front of you, and very helpful and polite staff both in reception and breakfast room that makes your stay even more enjoyable. Even thought not in centre of Rome, close enough by public transportation very easy and accesible: bus line 85 runs often one block from hotel, takes you to Colesseum and near Trevi? Metro linea B, about 5 blocks from hotel takes you to centre or Ananigna to take bus to Ciampino, and train to Fiumicino airport 2-3 blocks from hotel: only 5 euros takes you in a bit without stops. Only problem with Metro line B is that stopped working after 9:00PM. Hope it changes soon, but still OK. Would definitely reccomend hotel to anybody and cannot wait to go back now in June for 2 nights.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Hotel, Great Breakfast, Absolute Delight to stay in....”
Reviews.Author: bobchadda
Reviews.Content: I have never written a review in the past for any hotel property that i have stayed in, purely because i never really felt a need to, but having just returned from Rome, I am compelled to do so, and will do so on hotel propoerties i stay at in the future. The information i gathered from the tripadvisor website was invaluable, and the fact that i was taking my wife, who is 5 months pregnant for a short weekend away, it was more important to not really waste time or have any undue stress imposed on us. The directions that i took with me from a previous reviewer (Thanks Papaya9!), could not have been more precise and the journey from Airport to Hotel was easy, convenient and hassle free. As we had arrived at 8 in the evening, we were effortlessly checked-in, and were in our room within minutes of walking in through the main doors. We too tried a local restaurant, Sacco, within walking distance of the hotel ( and i mean an easy walk as do not forget I am with my pregnant wife here ) and the meal was fantastic, real great italian food, good service and a wonderful environment to be in. Also, as we were tired from the travelling, it was an ideal place to spend our first night in. With regards to getting around, the metro is a 10 minute walk away, the bus stop for the number 85 is at the bottom of the road that the hotel is on, both with easy and good connections to most of the places you would wish to go to in Rome. Visiting the sites was easy, although please be prepared for the queues. and a word of advice here: do check the opening times of the sites you wish to visit as we were caught short with the Cistine Chapel, which closed at 13:30 on the day we tried to visit, but as we couldn't get in it gives us a reason to head back again. With regards to getting back to the hotel, again the bus and metro is great, but should you need to use a taxi, look to pay around 10 euros, which is not a bad price to pay if it allows you to enjoy more of your time in the centre. We were also lucky to be told about the Travestere area, which has some really good restaurants in, and we stumbled across one, with the same name as the area, that was full of the locals, and we used that as a good sign as to how good it was. Boy, were we glad we gave it a go. The food was the best, the place had a powerful atmosphere and we actually ended up staying till closing, which is something impressive when you have a 5 month pregnant women enjoying the spoils of the night as companion. Back onto the hotel, the room are clean, the bathrooms clean yet small, but with nice hot showers. Don't expect panaramic views of Rome from your room. The breakfast was just great, looked after by a couple of lovely ladies. They make fresh capuccino's for you, and there is also a hot food selection available too. One thing is that there is no tip box in the breakfast lounge, so you either have to leave them something at the table or you don't. The hotel manager should take note and place a tip box there so one can show their appreciation for what the ladies provide in the morning. Either way, it was an enjoyable stay, the hotel was far better than i had expected for a Holiday Inn Express, and i really would not have an qualms about staying here again considering what you get for the price you pay.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place to stay”
Reviews.Author: gramager
Reviews.Content: We were in Rome in May 2006. Finding a hotel was key to our trip. We found this one on line and the price was good. When we got there we were plesantly surprised. The receptionists were very accomodating. We need a place to put luggage for 6 people who just finished a 26 day cruise. They had a room for all of it. Then they locked it up. While we waited for our room we were offered the option of having a little breakfast. When we went into the room we were amazed with the selection. There were eggs, sausage, sweet rolls. fruit, yogurt, and much more. After going to our room , which was larger than we thought it would be and appointed well. We went out and wandered around the area of the hotel. We found a little pizza place with a gelato place next door. There were severl restaurants around and we found a grocery store within walking distance. We had a tour for the next day but the following day we took the bus to the center of Rome. We then used the double decker bus to sightsee. The time at this area was very nice.

Reviews.Title: “Good modern hotel”
Reviews.Author: bronia
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a 4 night stay here.Booked this hotel after reading reviews on tripadvisor. Clean, modern rooms typical of the chain. Beds comfortable , good lighting and decor; hotel is fairly new I think. Location not central but good bus and metro connections; 5 minutes to bus which goes to colosseum and about 10 minutes to Ponte Lungo metro which takes you most places. Small supermarket on way from metro. Taxi to Ciampino 25 euros. Staff very friendly and efficient. Breakfast mainly continental type. Highly recommend this hotel. Would definitely stay here again. Noise from adjacent train station not too much of a distraction. Courtyard rooms quieter.

Reviews.Title: “Just perfect”
Reviews.Author: savon30
Reviews.Content: We chose this Express by Holiday Inn after having read many good critics about it on Tridadvisor internet site and we must say that we were very satisfied with our choice. Our 4-day trip to Rome was just perfect. The hotel is quite modern. The English-speaking staff at reception was very nice and helpful. The room was really clean and spacious. The buffet breakfast was the most amazing one we've ever seen in a hotel. The hotel is ideally located with a direct train from Fiumicino airport to the Tuscolana train station (€5 per person). It is not so far from the busy centre of Rome and 2 minutes away from the bus stop with a direct bus (#85) to the Colosseum. We were recommended 2 very good restaurants near the hotel which were very good : Pastarito where you can find fantastic pasta and Il Sacco which is more expensive but which offers real Italian cuisine. All in all we cannot find any drawbacks. We highly recommend this hotel to everyone.

Reviews.Title: “Very good hotel”
Reviews.Author: Davegol
Reviews.Content: This is a good hotel, it is very decent , nice rooms(though I'm not sure if it has air conditioning), it is very close to the Metro, which was our main transportation throughout our trip. it also has a bus station a minute away that is also very usefull. Money well spent!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent value but plan carefully”
Reviews.Author: xgeorgeAthens
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Express by Holiday in - San Giovanni in early December 2006. The hotel was an excellent bargain by Rome standards: we got the 14 day advance rate, which is restrictive but cheap, everything in the hotel is brand new, and yes, in addition to a great breakfast you also get a real espresso or capuccino made on the spot. The area is pretty decent and safe, there are people on the streets at least until 11 pm and there are places to eat and shop nearby. I was perfectly happy with the hotel and would definitely stay there again if I had a similar budget. While far from the center, indeed far even from San Giovanni in Laterano (two metro stops) where the city walls are, the hotel has good commuter connections. First, the nearby suburban railway (Tuscolana station) will get you to the airport at half price the price of the Leonardo Express to Termini, in the same time, and you will not have to change trains, plus it runs every 15 rather than 30 minutes on weekdays. It will also get you to Trastevere (a tram will get you closer to the center of trastevere) and various places around Rome. The second option is bus 85 to the center, with a stop right next to the suburban railway. As long as you avoid the rush hours of Rome, the bus is quite OK. The only trouble is that even though it runs until past 11 pm, there are few buses in the evening (e.g. every 30-40 minutes after 9 pm), so make sure you find out what the schedule is if you do not want to spend your time at the bus stop. The third option, which is normally the best, is the subway. Ponte Lungo station is 2 blocks away from the bus stop / commuter train station, and definitely worth the less than 5 min extra walking time. Metro line B will take you to a more central place from where you can walk or take a bus to the historic center (the subway does not run through the history center proper), or to Piazza di Spagna, Piazza del Popolo or close to the Vatican and St. Peter's. Trains run every 3-5 minutes, and get you everywhere so fast that I would have never taken the 85 bus if not for the subway issue mentioned below. The only bad news is that currently the subway stops service at 9 pm due to ongoing work on the lines, therefore you either have to return early to the hotel area, wait for the bus or take a taxi. In case of a bus/metro strike you will need to take a taxi anyway, as you cannot walk anywhere interesting. The taxi should cost between 10 (to the Coloseum) and 20 (to the Vatican), so it's not that expensive, but if you use it daily, maybe you should stay closer to the center and pay extra.

Reviews.Title: “Really great breakfast!”
Reviews.Author: mira74bela
Reviews.Content: According to all of the reviews, the holiday inn is great and it was. The room was clean and the size of the bed was between a queen and king size. The bathroom is small but, the shower is hot. They provide lots of nice, white clean towels. If you want to watch t.v. after a long day out there's only a few english channels mtv counting as one of them. It's 11 euros to watch an english speaking movie. Beware though---the price includes some unsavory channels too. The breakfast is really spectacular. There is fresh scrambled eggs, sausage and ham, all sorts of pastries, a fresh loaf of bread, yogurt (individual and large) and cereal. Coffee is fresh by the cup as well as grapefruit juice and orange juice. If you want a cappucino, you can ask and they will bring it to your table. The breakfast starts I think at 6:30 and ends at 10:30 a.m. If you're not an early riser don't worry because they will continue to replenish everything. The location is very good. Follow the directions on the hotel website and you will get there from the airport. If you are leaving at a difficult time, the hotel will arrange transportation to the airport for 50 euro. We usually stayed out all day long and took a cab home. If you say, "via assissi and tuscoluna" they can find it. We took cabs from Trastevere, Pantheon and near Piazza de spagna. All the rides were 10 euro. It's a quick walk around the block to the bus which you want to take towards San Silvestro #85. It's a quick walk to the subway too (Ponte Lungo).

Reviews.Title: “Very Decent hotel!”
Reviews.Author: Papaya9
Reviews.Content: This was a nice economy hotel not too far out of the way of the main Roman highlights. We stayed for a week and were very pleased with every aspect of the stay. The staff is young, attractive and has great attitude! Spoke English fluently, too. Breakfast is nicer than expected. The girls who set it up and maintain it are great. If you ask for a cappucino they make it so beautifully. I was disappointed that nobody ever left tips for them, since they do such a nice job. If you stay here be nice and leave a euro for them! They are great. The room was adequate, modern, and clean. The walls are a little bit on the thin side as we heard some clueless Russian women next door who once stayed up all night, but this was the only negative! This hotel is VERY easy to get to, even though it was a little confusing to find with what was written in prior reviews here. Don't ever think that this is difficult--so easy! When you arrive at the airport, look for the signs that direct you to the train station. You may want to pick up some money at the Bancomat ATM before you leave the terminal! Purchase your tickets at the ticket counter with the red motif surrounding it on the left as soon as you walk into the station. Look for the Orte-Fara Sabina Train. Take this train to the Tuscolana station after 35 minutes. When you get off the train, turn right and walk for about 25 ft to stairs going down. Take a left at the bottom of the stairs, walk straight back to the end and make a right up another flight of stairs. It will look a little scary when you step out of the stairwell, but rest assured its not as bad as it looks. Now follow the little path that arcs down and left. Turn left when you reach street level, and make the next left up Via Assisi. The hotel is about 100 ft on the left. Going to the sights is just as easy. The 85 bus takes you past the coloseum and up to the north part of the city. Enjoy!

Reviews.Title: “Good value & modern”
Reviews.Author: JJB
Reviews.Content: The hotel is ideal for the Fiumicino Airport. 5 euros for a 30-minute direct train trip (NOT the Leonardo Express) from Touscana train station , which is 10 minutes on foot from the hotel. I have no difficulties finding the hotel (even afte dark) following the instructions as posted in the hotel's website. Go straight for Lane 8, and you'll be on the right track. Via Assisi is the first street on the left. Breakfast is unexpectedly delightful and offers a lot of choices, hot and cold. I can't believe they offer such at no extra cost. I agree entirely with the fellow traveler that you don't get this even for paid ones. My only reservation with this clean, modern and spacious establishment is the air-con. I am not sure if it's my room (Rm 1026) or the overall facility - the heater was apparently too warm when I was there, and the "switch" inside the room did not seem to function. We were only there for a few hours (late arrival and a noon flight) so we did not bother to have the room changed. This room is facing the train station so having the windows opening helped cooling down a bit but unavoidably brought in the noise of the trains running throughout the night. Other than that we are very satisfied with our stay and will probably be back.

Reviews.Title: “Great place but prepare yourself!”
Reviews.Author: epapera
Reviews.Content: This hotel was very comfortable and clean on a whole. Its a chain and they uphold the standards of the Holiday Inns all over the place. The problem was the website address for this location. Be sure to call the place before you go because the directions are HORRIBLE to get from Termini to the hotel. I even had my husband reread it over and over again to understand them . They are just written poorly and really there are TWO train stations near this hotel. Tuscolana is the commuter train which will get you to Fumincino (FCO) and Ponte Lugo is the Metro train that is somewhat nearby. To get to the main attractions in Rome, you heavily rely on the public transportation near the hotel. The 85 busline runs right by the big side street near the hotel and that goes through one of the main veins through Rome (right by the Colosseum). Its not close to anything but the transportation can get you there!!! My husband and I never had to jump in a cab there as we really loved the public transportation (you do have to get used to the tons and tons of graffitti on the public vehicles though!!) The Metro station (to be honest) is not that close but it is useful when you need to make the trek to St. Peter's Basilica. All in all the breakfast was fantastic and the staff was so friendly and accomodating. We never ended up asking them for restaurant recommendations but they were really helpful getting us out and about in Rome. Rome was our last stop and I was really getting exhausted finding a good hotel that fit our budget. The Holiday Inn Express met our needs and I can't complain about the experience!!!

Reviews.Title: “good budget hotel”
Reviews.Author: canadabound
Reviews.Content: the hotel actually backs on to the railway so is definitely convenient for travel from Fuimicino airport to Tuscolana railway station.However arriving late at night as we did it can be a bit disorientating as there are 2 exits to the station.If you exit via a ramp onto the street and the railway bridge is on your right hand side-congatratulations you've found the most direct route as via Assisi is the next road on your left.However if you come out of the station with the car park in front of you you will need to turn left, left again under the railway bridge until you then get to via Assisi on your left. Travelling into Rome is very easy -we got the metro each day at 1 euro each way.We actually found it a benefit to be able to come back to a quiet residential area after a days sightseeing .There is a pasta/pizza restaurant very close to the hotel which seemed to be very popular with hotel residents.The breakfast provided by the hotel provided a good selection and was more than enough to set you up for the day.Hotel guests seemed to be from all nationalitiies but particularly Brits and Americans.Bedrooms are clean and spacious-we had a king size bed with a sofa bed for our 2 teenagers ,ideal for a short break

Reviews.Title: “Best 1 star hotel I have stayed at”
Reviews.Author: gardkarlsen
Reviews.Content: I was thrilled when I got the message that we would be going on a company trip to Rome. Since I had been there before I got the task of finding a hotel. Finding a hotel for 24 people in central Rome in October turned out to be quite a difficult task. Many of the centrally located hotels are smaller and many were fully booked. In the end we decided to stay at Express By Holiday Inn San Giovanni located at Via Assisi 53. We had to pay 125 € per room. Arriving in Rome We landed in Rome at about 11 am in the morning of October 21st. We walked over to the train station at Leonardo da Vinci airport also known as Fiumicino (FCO). From here you can take the Leonardo Express to Termini but since the hotel is located on the way we decided to go for a local train direction Orte-Fara Sabina for 5 € and after about 30-40 we reached the train station Rome Tuscolana. It was easy to find the hotel…we just followed the instructions from the hotel web site and it was only a 5-10 minute walk. The room I got a room on the first floor and the room itself must be one of the nicest rooms that I have seen in a 1 star hotel. The room was standard size with a blue carpet and yellow/light walls. The double bed was comfortable enough but there was only a blanket as a cover so it got a bit cold at night. There was an air con control on the wall but it didn’t seem like it was operational because nothing happened when I turned the knobs. There was also a desk and a chair in the room and a small color TV with some Italian, German and English channels. There was also quite a lot of hangers and that was useful since I had brought along a number of tops. I got a room for disabled people (is that the politically correct term?) and the bathroom was a bit strange due to this. The bathroom was tiled with white tiles and had a shower corner with a curtain to avoid spilling the water all over the room. There were no little bottles with shampoo etc that you find at some hotels…only a big Dove shower soap container on the wall. The drawbacks with the room in my opinion are the lack of a safe, lack of mini bar, the shower curtain and the view. From the ground floor I just looked right out on a concrete wall. Behind this wall or nearby was the railway and I was fearing that the noise would keep me up all night. But it was not as bad as I thought. The breakfast buffet was good with a selection of the standard bread, cereal, fruits and sweet cakes. The best of it all was the coffee machine that was in the room. It was possible to get a fresh made espresso, cappuccino etc and the coffee was great. The hotel has a nice inner courtyard that we used in connections with meetings that we had, for having a drink outside at night etc. I hope that we didn’t make to much noise because some of the rooms do face the courtyard. The reception area was small but there is a small bar there were you can get something to drink (beer, wine, coffee etc) and there is also a PC where you can access the internet for a few Euros. The hotel has a wireless internet so if you bring your laptop you can get online for a fee. Location The area around the hotel is not that exciting but it was pretty easy to get into town. We normally took the metro and the nearest metro station is Ponte Lungo which is a 10 minute walk from the hotel. On line A you can reach Termini (to switch to get to Collosseum), Spagna (the Spanish Steps), Barberini (Trevi fountain) etc. A taxi back to the hotel at night was not that expensive either…I think we paid about 10-15 €. Conclusion We paid 125 € for the rooms and for a 1 star hotel the standard was very good. The service from the staff was also great. The “problem” with this hotel is the location related to the city and the minor drawbacks that I have mentioned already in this review. If you can’t find a hotel in town this is absolutely a good alternative. Check out more info on the hotel homepage [-]

Reviews.Title: “Good value & comfortable hotel for Rome”
Reviews.Author: LittleAffy
Reviews.Content: This hotel looks like it was recently renovated. Our room on the first floor was spotless, a decent size (rare for Rome hotels) and with a new bathroom. The air conditioning was great as it was still hot even at night in Rome during October. The breakfast provided a great range of foods - everything from cereal, fruit and yohurt to cakes, eggs, many types of breads, etc. The location is about 5 kms from the city centre, however it still took up to 45 mins to get to the centre of Rome during preak hour traffic. Two options for getting into the Rome CBD are bus 85 which leaves from a bus stop about a 5 min walk from the hotel. There is also a train station next door. I found this hotel to be much more reasonably priced vs other hotels in Rome and I recommend putting up with the travel time to the centre of Rome in order to save a few dollars. Staff at reception could speak english and were helpful in providing transportation tips and restaurant recommendations.

Reviews.Title: “Loved Rome and this hotel”
Reviews.Author: mkannur
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Holiday Inn Express Rome San Giovanni simply going by what others had to say about the place in Tripadvisor. I am glad I did that. I got a good price on the hiexpress website by booking in advance. Though the hotel is not right in the heart of the city, it is a very convenient to get there by bus. We also used the sub way station but that was a longer walk. The rooms are very clean and modern. The front desk staff are helpful . Breakfast was good with a lot of choice. Would definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “A Great Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: godsid
Reviews.Content: We've stayed at the "Express by Holiday Inn" hotel for 4 nights during our visit to Rome. Other than its somewhat remote location (not a problem!), which probably affects the affordable pricing, the hotel is great. The rooms are squeaky clean, breakfast is wonderful and ample and the staff is courteous, nice and helpful. Besides twisting our suitcase handle, which was compensated for with hotel billing credit, our stay was *great*. A few tips: 1. The Punte Lungo metro station is a 10 minute walk from the hotel. You can alternatively use the 85 line bus during the night (when the metro is closed) or early morning. The 85 bus station is located within a 3 minute walking distance. 2. Try asking for a room with a balcony in advance (104-110). 3. There is no room-safe. You need to use the reception desk's main safe. 4. Laura (hotel staff / on duty manager) was just a charm! She was very helpful, nice and friendly. Always with a smile. Thanks!

Reviews.Title: “Good value for money”
Reviews.Author: ceb58
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 4 nights recently. Rooms very clean, bed large and comfortable, great breakfast, with good coffee made on demand. The staff were very helpful, storing our luggage when we arrived early and left late, gave us a useful map and instructions to the nearby metro station. booked us a taxi on the last day (tube strike!) and recommended a great restaurant nearby. The tube closes just after 9pm but taxi's are 10 - 14 eruos and we ate twice at the I Torquati restaurant just 10 minutes walk away from the hotel. The best steaks we have ever eaten and great pasta, going by the photos the Roma football team like eating here too. Book a table though, if you want to eat after 9pm. Really close to the train station for Leonardo Da Vinci airport and the right side of town for Ciampino airport.

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay!”
Reviews.Author: paris1949
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a 3-night stay at the hotel. We had three rooms (five adults) and we all found the rooms to be clean, quiet and well equipped. The hotel staff were friendly and helpful and most spoke English well. To illustrate their helpfulness---a story. I managed to leave my camera behind at a restuarant on the last night of our stay in Rome. Before checking out of the hotel the next day I asked one of the staff for suggestions on how I might retrieve my camera. He offered to go to the hotel when it opened later that day, hopefully retrieve my camera and have it shipped to me at my next destination in Tuscany. To my delight he recovered my camera and arranged for a courier to ship it to me (unfortunately the courier company took five days to get it to me but that's another story). The buffet breakfast was just fine with lots of variety. It is only a 5-10 minute walk from the hotel to the nearest subway station (Ponte Lungo) and there are lots of great restuarants in the vicinity of the hotel. We can definitely recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Very affordable place to stay in Rome”
Reviews.Author: Muscade
Reviews.Content: We stayed in this hotel for 5 nights in June 2006. We arrived by train from the airport. The hotel was easy to find but it was difficult with our luggages because of the stairs at the station. We arrived early but were able to get our room right away. The room was what you will expect from a Holliday Inn. Very clean. Bathroom small but immaculate. The hotel was about 10 minutes by foot from a metro station. It took us about 1/2 hour to get to the main attractions. There was a supermarket on our way to the metro which was very convenient. Breakfast was excellent with cappucino on demand. It was served in a small room but we preferred to eat on the adjoining terrace. To the usual they added something special everday: coffee cakes, bruschettas, mascarpone mousse etc. The surroundings were really safe. Not a lot of restaurants to choose from though. We ate at a nearby pasta chain restaurant a couple of times and it was great. We travelled with our 15 years old daughter and she liked the place. it was not the most typical "roman" place but there was no bad surprise.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location, Great value”
Reviews.Author: Patrick-advise
Reviews.Content: Great Location to the east of Rome. Nice and safe neighborhood. Conveniently located to the railway station with direct connection to the airport. Great value.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel for the Money!”
Reviews.Author: Johnandjoy
Reviews.Content: This hotel was the cheapest option we could find in Rome for 2 adults and a child. The service was good and the hotel was fresh and clean with adequate facilities and a great breakfast included. It is 5 minutes walk to the metro and another 10 minutes to the centre but this was no problem. The area seemed fine. Would definitely stay here again. A sofabed was laid out and made up for the child when we arrived.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place”
Reviews.Author: Amberish
Reviews.Content: Holiday Inn - San Giovanni To get to the hotel From airport, take the train going to trastevere and beyond. Make sure you do not get on to the Leonado Express which goes non-stop to the central train station. On the train get off at tuscolana station, get out and turn right… go under the subway and Via Assisi is on your left at the next intersection. Walk UP Via Assisi and you shall get to the hotel in 5 mins. Hotel Very nice hotel with comfortable and spacious room and more than helpful hotel staff. Comfortably accessible from the airport and comfortably close to all tourist attractions (Euro 1 one way ticket, bus no. 85 passing through nearly all major tourist spots. A first look at the surrounding area might suggest that this is nowhere close to where and how the medieval/ancient city of Rome would be, but remember, its just a 10 min bus ride away. So, enjoy the solitude. Hotel has a safe deposit box where you can deposit the passports, money etc, which can let you roam around in Rome carefree. Food: Breakfast buffet is highly recommended, with yoghurt, bread, bacon, coffee, juices, croissant, cakes, etc of all varieties. For lunch and dinner: - Sacco is a restaurant on a lane which turns right after you walk a bit further UP Via Assisi. Seemed to us to be a bit expensive, but then I/We are blokes from a third world country, with a very weak currency  - Turn left after you walk down from Via Assisi where it meets the boulevard.. at some 500 mts you will get an eatery called Gallo Umbro. The pizzas and assorted meats are recommended. Cheap place, too. - Right opposite the spot where Via Assisi meets the boulevard is a Pizza/Pasta joint called, well… Pizzarito Pastarito ! Nice place, good ambience, and yes, awesome pasta. All in all, good place, nice rooms, good location and you can get a good price if you book early. Recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This was a surprisingly wonderful stay. The room was clean and comfortable. The bathroom was also clean and spacious, with a great shower. The breakfast here was excellent! We weren’t expecting greatness, because it is only a Holiday-Inn Express, but it was a great spread. Breads, yogurts, eggs, bacon, sausage, juice, coffee, cereal, meats, cheeses—yummy! The best part about the hotel, was the people at the front desk. They were all very helpful, friendly, and professional. They actually cared about us having a good time in Rome and a pleasant stay at the hotel. They weren’t faking it. They went out of their way to ensure we had a good time. The location of the hotel is good. It is about a quarter of a mile to the subway station, and from there it is a 5 minute ride to the Coliseum. You could even walk to the Coliseum from the hotel in about 30 minutes or so. Vatican City is about 20 minutes by subway from the hotel. Overall, a very good stay—highly recommended.

HotelInfo.Name: Holiday Inn Express Rome - San Giovanni
HotelInfo.Address: Via Assisi 53, 00181 Rome, Italy
